captions.text:
The snooze button, one of man's best
inventions...until nine minutes later when

the dreaded alarm strikes again.  Except
now you feel even more tired, so do you

hit it again?  Are those extra minutes
really helping at all? Or is it the

beginning of a never-ending cycle that
ends in you being late and still dead tired.

In an unimaginable world without alarm
clocks our bodies would simply wake up

naturally, seems crazy right?  But our
bodies have many chemical mechanisms in

place to not only put us to sleep, 
but wake us up as well.  The body begins

preparing in the hour before you
naturally wake-up, body temperature rises

sleep becomes lighter and hormones such as
dopamine and cortisol are released

which give you energy to start your day.
 But the problem with alarms is that they
often interrupt your sleep cycle and cut these processes short.  Particularly if you

don't have a regular sleep rhythm or
schedule, the alarm goes off, but your body
isn't quite ready.  This groggy and tired state is known as "sleep intertia"

and its strength is related to which
sleep stage you are waking up out of.

The deeper the sleep the more potent the
sleep inertia and so the snoozing

begins.  But the snooze button can do more
damage than good, as you fall back asleep

the body be restart its sleep cycle and
enter into deeper sleep stages.  So

instead of your body prepping to wake up,
it's going in the opposite direction and

as a result the second alarm may cause
you to feel even more tired
and so continues the viscious cycle.
Ultimately. you would be better off setting your original alarm later and not

interrupting your sleep.  Many studies
have found that fragmented sleep is much
less restorative

and leads to sleepiness related daytime
impairment.  So by breaking up those last

thirty minutes or so of sleep, you are
more likely to feel tired and perform

poorly during the day.  What else can you do?
Try adopting a more regular sleep

schedule, being tired is not only a
product of sleep deprivation or waking

up out of a deep sleep, but also lacking a
consistent schedule.  The body loves

predictability, wake up at the same time
every morning, including the weekends, and

after a few weeks your body should adapt
to the timing and be less inclined to

require an alarm in the first place.  And
if you do wake up feeling a little

tired, try to resist the snooze
temptation and just get up,
because as the saying goes "you snooze you lose".
Got a burning question you want answered? Ask it in the comments, or on facebook and twitter.
And subscribe for more weekly science videos.

title: Should You Use The SNOOZE Button?

comments.author: Miranda Samuelsson

comments.author: Miranda Samuelsson

comments.text:
Because your Dad's call to "Wake Up!" is likely a much more 
pleasant-sounding and less *alarming* way to be woken up than by an 
annoying alarm clock going "BEEP BEEP BEEP" or "BRIIIIIIIIIIINNNG!"

You probably also feel more responsible to your Dad to wake up right away 
and get up, but less responsible (and more likely to micro-snooze) in 
response to your perturbing alarm clock. And as the video indicates, 
snoozing (even for a minute or two) will make you groggy and tired.

Hey! I have a question about how nicotine affects the body (like digestive

called SNUS that you put under your lip, which containes a lot more 
nicotine than a sigarette (3,2 - 8,3 mg nicotine pr 2,5 g SNUS vs. 1 mg 
nicotine pr sigarette). Most people I know, including me uses up about 17g 
snus pr day! So, many of us are in a constant nicotine buzz (there's no 
problem having this in your mouth while showering, exercising etc) and I 
guess I hope a video from you guys about this highly addictive monster of 
an invention will help on my and others motivation to quit. You have fans 
in Scandinavia! Yey!﻿

comments.author: Christine Moffat

comments.text:
I had a really bad experience with interrupting deep sleep and 4 months 
later I'm still suffering the effects! When I had my baby things didn't go 
exactly according to plan and  I ended up not being to go home straight 
away... after the doctors broke my waters, gave me hormones, etc etc, over 
24 hours later my baby was finally born! I don't what it was but I just 
couldn't sleep but finally towards the end of the day I started getting 
tired and sleepy. Now... my partner wasn't allowed to stay at the hospital 
with me, so after he went home I finally closed my eyes... only to be woken 
up by my baby! I did what I had to do and put him down to sleep again.. but 
he kept waking up! After trying so many times (4 hours laters) I decided to 
bring him to my bed but again... I couldn't sleep! I was afraid because I 
was so tired I'd fall asleep deeply and hurt him without noticing. I kept 
forcing myself to stay awake and if I fell asleep it was never for long.. 
it was like my head had its own alarm clock.. Well, hours and hours passed, 
the staff started to give breakfast and my partner arrived "where did time 
go?" still.. I couldn't sleep!! Every time I was sleeping really well, I 
was interrupted by some doctor wanting a blood sample, or a nurse giving me 
medication or doing obs :( After a while I started to feel really energetic 
but very light headed and felt some numbness... even my tongue was numb.. I 
don't know how things went, all I know is that all of a sudden the numbness 
got worse, I could walk fine but at the same time I couldn't feel my legs 
properly, I started having twitches with my eyes, mouth, tongue, then arms, 
legs and eventually having full body spasms (they even thought I was 
epileptic).. I still felt like I didn't want to sleep though.. apparently 
because I was so tired after labour but my sleep was interrupted all the 
time, my brain decided to go all weird and act as if I needed to sleep but 
didn't send the message to tell me I was sleepy. I needed pills to teach my 
brain how to sleep again but now, 4 months later I still get twitches 
(mainly just with my eyes and mouth) if I start getting really tired and 
had a few more episodes of full body spasms when I was really stressed!  ﻿
